Interface Monad<O,M>

All Superinterfaces:
Functor<O,M,O,M>
public interface Monad<O,M> extends Functor<O,M,O,M>
Represents a Monad in Category Theory.

A Monad on a category C is an endofunctor T: C Ã¢â€ â€™ C equipped with two natural transformations:

  • Unit (ÃŽÂ·): Id Ã¢â€ â€™ T
  • Multiplication (ÃŽÂ¼): TÃ‚Â² Ã¢â€ â€™ T
satisfying associativity and identity laws.

In computer science, Monads are used to model computations with side effects (state, I/O, exceptions, non-determinism).

Since:
1.0
Author:
Silvere Martin-Michiellot, Gemini AI (Google DeepMind)

    • unit

      M unit(O object)
      The unit natural transformation (ÃŽÂ·). Lifts a value into the monadic context. Also known as 'return' or 'pure'.
      Parameters:
      object - the object to lift
      Returns:
      the morphism from object to T(object)

    • join

      M join(O nestedObject)
      The multiplication natural transformation (ÃŽÂ¼). Flattens a nested monadic value. Also known as 'join' or 'flatten'.
      Parameters:
      nestedObject - the object representing T(T(x))
      Returns:
      the morphism from T(T(x)) to T(x)
